parameter provides the expression to evaluate, the second the encoding to apply
if the expression is true, the third the encoding if the expression is false.
values.type: VegaLite.BooleanOp -> List.List VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel -> List.List VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel -> VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel

values.name: hGeo
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a hyperlink property is a geo feature.
Equivalent to `hMType GeoFeature`.

values.name: hMType
values.comment:
Level of measurement when encoding with a hyperlink or url channel. See also
[hNominal](#hNominal), [hOrdinal](#hOrdinal), [hQuant](#hQuant), [hTemporal](#hTemporal)
and [hGeo](#hGeo) for shorthand equivalents.

values.name: hName
values.comment: Name of field used for encoding with a hyperlink channel.

values.name: hNominal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a hyperlink or url property is nominal.
Equivalent to `hMType Nominal`.

values.name: hOrdinal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a hyperlink property is ordinal. Equivalent to
`hMType Ordinal`.

values.name: hQuant
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a hyperlink or url property is quantitative.
Equivalent to `hMType Quantitative`.

values.name: hRepeat
values.comment:
Reference in a hyperlink channel to a field name generated by [repeatFlow](#repeatFlow)
or [repeat](#repeat). The parameter identifies whether reference is being made to
fields that are to be arranged in columns, in rows or a with a flow layout.

values.name: hSelectionCondition
values.comment:
Make a hyperlink channel conditional on interactive selection. The first parameter
provides the selection to evaluate, the second the encoding to apply if the hyperlink
has been selected, the third the encoding if it is not selected.
values.type: VegaLite.BooleanOp -> List.List VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel -> List.List VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel -> VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel

values.name: hStr
values.comment: Literal string value when encoding with a hyperlink channel.

values.name: hTemporal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a hyperlink or url property is temporal.
Equivalent to `hMType Temporal`.

values.name: hTimeUnit
values.comment: Time unit aggregation of field values when encoding with a hyperlink channel.

values.name: haCenter
values.comment: Center horizontal text alignment.

values.name: haLeft
values.comment: Left horizontal text alignment.

values.name: haRight
values.comment: Right horizontal text alignment.

values.name: hcl
values.comment: HCL color interpolation for continuous color scales.

values.name: hclLong
values.comment: HCL color interpolation in polar coordinate space for continuous color scales.

values.name: hdFormat
values.comment:
[Formatting pattern](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/format.html) for
facet header (title) values. To distinguish between formatting as numeric values
and data/time values, additionally use [hdFormatAsNum](#hdFormatAsNum) or
[hdFormatAsTemporal](#hdFormatAsTemporal).

values.name: hdFormatAsNum
values.comment:
Indicate that facet headers should be formatted as numbers. To control the
precise numeric format, additionally use [hdFormat](#hdFormat) providing a
[d3 numeric format string](https://github.com/d3/d3-format#locale_format).

values.name: hdFormatAsTemporal
values.comment:
Indicate that facet headers should be formatted as dates/times. To control the
precise temporal format, additionally use [hdFormat](#hdFormat) providing a
[d3 date/time format string](https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format).

values.name: hdLabelAlign
values.comment:
Horizontal alignment of header labels. A 'label' is the
title for each sub-plot in a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelAnchor
values.comment:
Anchor position of header labels. A 'label' is the title for each sub-plot
in a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelAngle
values.comment:
Header label rotation angle (in degrees from horizontal) for a faceted view.
A 'label' is the title for each sub-plot in a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelColor
values.comment: Header label text color for a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelFont
values.comment: Header label font for a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelFontSize
values.comment: Header label font size for a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelLimit
values.comment: Maximum length of a header label in a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelOrient
values.comment:
The position of a header label relative to a sub-plot. A 'label' is the title
for each sub-plot in a faceted view.

values.name: hdLabelPadding
values.comment: Spacing in pixels between facet labels and the main plot area.

values.name: hdTitle
values.comment:
Header title in a faceted view. A 'title' is the overall title describing
the collection of faceted plots.

values.name: hdTitleAlign
values.comment: Horizontal alignment of header title in a faceted view.

values.name: hdTitleAnchor
values.comment: Anchor position of a header title in a faceted view.

values.name: hdTitleAngle
values.comment: Text angle of a header title in a faceted view (degrees from horizontal).

values.name: hdTitleFontWeight
values.comment: Title font weight in a faceted view.

values.name: hdTitleLimit

values.name: hdTitleOrient
values.comment:
The position of a header title relative to a group of sub-plots in a faceted

values.name: height
values.comment:
Override the default height of the visualization. If not specified the height
will be calculated based on the content of the visualization. How the content is
sized relative to this height specification can be customised with [autosize])(#autosize).

values.name: heightStep
values.comment:
Set the height of the discrete y-field (e.g. individual bars in a horizontal
bar chart). The total height is then calculated based on the number of discrete
fields (e.g. bars).

    toVegaLite [ heightStep 17, data [], enc [], bar [] ]

values.name: hours
values.comment: Hour of the day time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: hoursMinutes
values.comment: Hours and minutes time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: hoursMinutesSeconds
values.comment: Hours, minutes and seconds time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: hsl
values.comment: HSL color interpolation for continuous color scales.

values.name: hslLong
values.comment: HSL color interpolation in polar coordinate space for continuous color scales.

values.name: hyperlink
values.comment:
Encode a hyperlink channel. The first parameter is a list of hyperlink channel
properties that characterise the hyperlinking such as the destination URL and cursor
type.

    encData =
        encoding
            << hyperlink [ hName "url", hNominal ]

    encLiteral =
        encoding
            << hyperlink [ hStr "http://www.imdb.com" ]
values.type: List.List VegaLite.HyperlinkChannel -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: iCheckbox
values.comment: Checkbox input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iColor
values.comment: Color input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iDate
values.comment: Date input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iDateTimeLocal
values.comment: Local time input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iMonth
values.comment: Month input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iNumber
values.comment: Number input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iRadio
values.comment: Radio box input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iRange
values.comment: Range slider input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iSelect
values.comment: Select input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iTel
values.comment: Telephone number input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iText
values.comment: Text input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iTime
values.comment: Time input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: iWeek
values.comment: Week input element that can bound to a named field value.

values.name: identityProjection
values.comment:
An 'identity' projection where longitude is projected directly to the x position
and latitude to the y position. Can also reflect either of the coordinates by
specifying [prReflectX](#prReflectX) / [prReflectY](#prReflectY) in the list of
projection properties.

values.name: imFrame
values.comment:
1d window over which data imputation values are generated. The two
parameters should either be `Just` a number indicating the offset from the current
data object, or `Nothing` to indicate unbounded rows preceding or following the
current data object.

values.name: imGroupBy
values.comment:
Allow imputing of missing values on a per-group basis. For use with the impute
transform only and not a channel encoding.

values.name: imKeyValSequence
values.comment:
Key values to be considered for imputation as a sequence of numbers between
a start (first parameter), to less than an end (second parameter) in steps of
the third parameter.

values.name: imKeyVals
values.comment: Key values to be considered for imputation.

values.name: imMax
values.comment: Use maximum of values when imputing missing data.

values.name: imMean
values.comment: Use mean of values when imputing missing data.

values.name: imMedian
values.comment: Use median of values when imputing missing data.

values.name: imMethod
values.comment: Imputation method to use when replacing values.

values.name: imMin
values.comment: Use maximum of values when imputing missing data.

values.name: imNewValue
values.comment: New value to use when imputing with [imValue](#imValue).

values.name: imValue
values.comment: Use field value when imputing missing data.

values.name: image
values.comment:
[Image mark](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/image.html) for displaying
an image. The parameter is a list of standard mark properties for customising the
image. The image files to be displayed should be specified via the [url](#url)
channel. Normally, the width and height of the image should be specified with
[maWidth](#maWidth) and [maHeight](#maHeight).

    let
        data =
            dataFromColumns []
                << dataColumn "x" (nums [ 0.5, 1.5, 2.5 ])
                << dataColumn "y" (nums [ 0.5, 1.5, 2.5 ])

        enc =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "x", pQuant ]
                << position Y [ pName "y", pQuant ]
                << url [ hStr "myImage.png" ]
    in
    toVegaLite [ data [], enc [], image [ maWidth 50, maHeight 25 ] ]

Alternatively, data-driven images can be used by referencing a data field containing
image URLs.

    let
        data =
            dataFromColumns []
                << dataColumn "x" (nums [ 0.5, 1.5, 2.5 ])
                << dataColumn "y" (nums [ 0.5, 1.5, 2.5 ])
                << dataColumn "img" (strs [ "img1.png", "img2.png", "img3.png" ])

        enc =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "x", pQuant ]
                << position Y [ pName "y", pQuant ]
                << url [ hName "img", hNominal ]
    in
    toVegaLite [ data [], enc [], image [ maWidth 30, maHeight 30 ] ]

values.name: impute
values.comment:
Impute missing data values as a data transform. The first parameter is the
data field to process; the second the key field to uniquely identify data objects
within a group; the third customisable options.

For example, to impute the missing value of `b` with the mean of existing `b` values,
when `a` is 30 and its color group (`c`) is 1:

    let
        data =
            dataFromColumns []
                << dataColumn "a" (nums [ 0, 0, 10, 10, 20, 20, 30 ])
                << dataColumn "b" (nums [ 28, 91, 43, 55, 81, 53, 19 ])
                << dataColumn "c" (nums [ 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 ])

        trans =
            transform
                << impute "b" "a" [ imMethod imMean, imGroupBy [ "c" ] ]

        enc =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "a", pMType Quantitative ]
                << position Y [ pName "b", pMType Quantitative ]
                << color [ mName "c", mMType Nominal ]
    in
    toVegaLite [ data [], trans [], enc [], line [] ]
values.type: String.String -> String.String -> List.List VegaLite.ImputeProperty -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: inDebounce
values.comment:
Delay to introduce when processing input events in order to avoid unnecessary
event broadcasting.

values.name: inElement
values.comment:
CSS selector indicating the parent element to which an input element should
be added. Allows the option of the input element to be outside the visualization
container.

values.name: inMax
values.comment: Maximum slider value for a range input element.

values.name: inMin
values.comment: Minimum slider value for a range input element.

values.name: inName
values.comment: Custom label for a radio or select input element.

values.name: inOptions
values.comment: Options for a radio or select input element.

values.name: inPlaceholder
values.comment: Initial place-holding text for input elements such as text fields.

values.name: inStep
values.comment: Minimum input element range slider increment.

values.name: joBevel
values.comment: Bevelled stroke join.

values.name: joMiter
values.comment: Mitred stroke join.

values.name: joRound
values.comment: Rounded stroke join.

values.name: joinAggregate
values.comment:
Aggregation transformations to be used when encoding channels. Unlike
[aggregate](#aggregate), this transformation joins the results to the input data.
Can be helpful for creating derived values that combine raw data with some aggregate
measure, such as percentages of group totals. The first parameter is a list
of the named aggregation operations to apply. The second is a list of possible
window aggregate field properties, such as a field to group by when aggregating.
The third parameter is a list of transformations to which this is added.

    transform
        << joinAggregate [ opAs opMean "rating" "avYearRating" ]
            [ wiGroupBy [ "year" ] ]
        << filter (fiExpr "(datum.rating - datum.avYearRating) > 3")

For details, see the
[Vega-Lite join aggregate documentation](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/joinaggregate.html)
values.type: List.List VegaLite.Spec -> List.List VegaLite.WindowProperty -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: jsonProperty
values.comment:
Property to be extracted from some JSON when it has some surrounding structure.
e.g., specifying the property `values.features` is equivalent to retrieving
`json.values.features` from a JSON object with a custom delimiter.

values.name: lab
values.comment: Lab color interpolation for continuous color scales.

values.name: layer
values.comment:
Assign a list of specifications to superposed layers in a visualization.
For example, adding text annotations to a bar chart:

    let
        data =
            dataFromColumns []
                << dataColumn "x" (nums [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ])
                << dataColumn "a" (nums [ 28, 91, 43, 55, 81 ])

        enc =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "x", pMType Ordinal ]
                << position Y [ pName "a", pMType Quantitative ]
                << text [ tName "a", tMType Nominal ]
    in
    toVegaLite
        [ data []
        , enc []
        , layer
            [ asSpec [ bar [] ]
            , asSpec [ textMark [ maDy -8 ], enc [] ]
            ]
        ]

values.name: leFormatAsNum

Indicate that legend labels should be formatted as numbers. To control the precise

values.name: leFormatAsTemporal

Indicate that legend labels should be formatted as dates/times. To control the

Offset in pixels of a legend from the encoded marks it describes. If the legend

values.name: line
values.comment:
[Line mark](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/line.html) for symbolising
a sequence of values.

values.name: lmMarker
values.comment:
Properties of a line marker that is overlaid on an area mark. Used
when specifying an [maLine](#maLine).

values.name: lmNone
values.comment: Indicates no line marker on an area mark.

values.name: loBottom
values.comment: Position legend outside and below the visualization it describes.

values.name: loBottomLeft
values.comment: Position legend within the visualization it describes in the bottom-left corner.

values.name: loBottomRight
values.comment: Position legend within the visualization it describes in the bottom-right corner.

values.name: loLeft
values.comment: Position legend to the left of the visualization it describes.

values.name: loNone
values.comment:
Do not perform automatic legend positioning (allows legend to be located explicitly
via `x` `y` coordinates).

values.name: loRight
values.comment: Position legend outside and to the right of the visualization it describes.

values.name: loTop
values.comment: Position legend outside and above the visualization it describes.

values.name: loTopLeft
values.comment: Position legend within the visualization it describes in the top-left corner.

values.name: loTopRight
values.comment: Position legend within the visualization it describes in the top-right corner.

values.name: loess
values.comment:
Generate a _loess_ (locally-estimated scatterplot smoothing) trendline through
a pair of data fields. The first parameter is the name of the field representing
the dependent variable (commonly mapped to the y-axis), the second is the name of
the field representing the independent variable (commonly mapped to the x-axis).
The third parameter is a list of optional loess parameters to customise the trend
fitting.
values.type: String.String -> String.String -> List.List VegaLite.LoessProperty -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: lookup
values.comment:
Perform a lookup of named fields between two data sources. This allows you to
find values in one data source based on the values in another. The first parameter
is the field in the primary data source to act as key, the second is the secondary
data source which can be specified with a call to `dataFromUrl` or other data
generating function. The third is the name of the field in the secondary
data source to match values with the primary key. The fourth parameter is the list
of fields to be stored when the keys match.

A common use for lookup is to join geographic and attribute data sources. Below
`geodata` is the primary data source containing borough boundaries and `carData`
the secondary data source containing attribute data. Both have a common data field
`boroughs` that is used to join the data sources:

    geoData =
        dataFromUrl "city.json" [ topojsonFeature "boroughs" ]

    carData =
        dataFromUrl "carOwnership.csv" []

    trans =
        transform
            << lookup "id"
                (carData [])
                "borough"
                [ "carOwnership" ]
values.type: String.String -> VegaLite.Data -> String.String -> List.List String.String -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: lookupAs
values.comment:
Similar to [lookup](#lookup) but returns the entire set of field values from
the secondary data source when keys match. Accessed via the name provided in the
fourth parameter. For a lookup that returns multiple fields, use dot notation to
access individual fields. For example,

    data =
        dataFromUrl "data/flights-airport.csv" []

    trans =
        transform
            << lookupAs "origin"
                (dataFromUrl "data/airports.csv" [])
                "iata"
                "o"

    enc =
        encoding
            << position Longitude
                [ pName "o.longitude"
                , pMType Quantitative
                ]
            << position Latitude
                [ pName "o.latitude"
                , pMType Quantitative
                ]
values.type: String.String -> VegaLite.Data -> String.String -> String.String -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: lsAs
values.comment:
Name the outputs of a loess transform. The first parameter is the name to
give the field containing the smoothed independent variable, the second the name to
give the field containing smoothed dependent variable. If not specified, the
original input independent and dependent field names are used.

values.name: lsBandwidth
values.comment:
The bandwidth scaled between [0,1] to determine the amount of loess smoothing.
Default value is 0.3

values.name: lsGroupBy
values.comment:
The data fields to group by when generating a loess trendline. If not specified,
a single group containing all data objects will be used.

values.name: mAggregate
values.comment:
Compute some aggregate summary statistics for a field to be encoded with a
mark property channel. The type of aggregation is determined by the given operation
parameter.

values.name: mBin
values.comment: Discretize numeric values into bins when encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: mBinned
values.comment: Indicate that data encoding with a mark are already binned.

values.name: mBoo
values.comment: Boolean value when encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: mDataCondition
values.comment:
Make a mark channel conditional on one or more predicate expressions. The first
parameter is a list of tuples each pairing a test condition with the encoding if
that condition evaluates to true. The second is the encoding if none of the tests
are true.

    color
        [ mDataCondition [ ( expr "datum.myField === null", [ mStr "grey" ] ) ]
            [ mStr "black" ]
        ]
values.type: List.List ( VegaLite.BooleanOp, List.List VegaLite.MarkChannel ) -> List.List VegaLite.MarkChannel -> VegaLite.MarkChannel

values.name: mGeo
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a mark property is a geo feature. Equivalent
to `mMType GeoFeature`.

values.name: mLegend
values.comment:
Properties of a legend that describes a mark's encoding. For no legend, provide
an empty list as the parameter.

values.name: mMType
values.comment:
Level of measurement when encoding with a mark property channel. See also
[nNominal](#mNominal), [mOrdinal](#mOrdinal), [mQuant](#mQuant), [mTemporal](#mTemporal)
and [mGeo](#mGeo) for shorthand equivalents.

values.name: mName
values.comment: Name of field used for encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: mNominal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a mark property is nominal. Equivalent to
`mMType Nominal`.

values.name: mNum
values.comment: Literal numeric value when encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: mOrdinal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a mark property is ordinal. Equivalent to
`mMType Ordinal`.

values.name: mPath
values.comment:
SVG path string used when encoding with a mark property channel. Useful
for providing custom shapes.

values.name: mQuant
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a mark property is quantitative. Equivalent to
`mMType Quantitative`.

values.name: mRepeat
values.comment:
Reference in a mark channel to a field name generated by [repeatFlow](#repeatFlow)
or [repeat](#repeat). The parameter identifies whether reference is being made to
fields that are to be arranged in columns, in rows or a with a flow layout.

values.name: mScale
values.comment:
Scaling applied to a field when encoding with a mark property channel.
The scale will transform a field's value into a color, shape, size etc.

values.name: mSelectionCondition
values.comment:
Make a mark channel conditional on interactive selection. The first parameter
is a selection condition to evaluate; the second the encoding to apply if that selection
is true; the third parameter is the encoding if the selection is false.

    color
        [ mSelectionCondition (selectionName "myBrush")
            [ mName "myField", mMType Ordinal ]
            [ mStr "grey" ]
        ]
values.type: VegaLite.BooleanOp -> List.List VegaLite.MarkChannel -> List.List VegaLite.MarkChannel -> VegaLite.MarkChannel

values.name: mSort
values.comment: Sort order when encoding sortable mark properties such as colour.

values.name: mStr
values.comment: Literal string value when encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: mTemporal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a mark property is temporal. Equivalent to
`mMType Temporal`.

values.name: mTimeUnit
values.comment: Time unit aggregation of field values when encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: mTitle
values.comment: Title of a field when encoding with a mark property channel.

values.name: maAlign
values.comment: Horizontal alignment of a text mark.

values.name: maAngle
values.comment: Rotation angle of a text mark (degrees from horizontal).

values.name: maAspect
values.comment: Whether or not the aspect ratio of an image mark should be preserved.

values.name: maBandSize
values.comment: Band size of a bar mark.

values.name: maBaseline
values.comment: Vertical alignment of a text mark.

values.name: maBinSpacing
values.comment: Offset between bars for a binned field using a bar mark.

values.name: maBorders
values.comment: Border properties for an errorband mark.

values.name: maBox
values.comment: Box symbol properties for the boxplot mark.

values.name: maClip
values.comment: Whether or not a mark should be clipped to the enclosing group's dimensions.

values.name: maColor
values.comment:
Default color of a mark. Note that `maFill` and `maStroke` have higher
precedence and will override this if specified. Color strings can use any valid
HTML color specification. For example,

    maColor "#eee"

    maColor "#734FD8"

    maColor "crimson"

    maColor "rgb(255,204,210)"

    maColor "hsl(180, 50%, 50%)"

values.name: maColorGradient
values.comment:
A color gradient to apply to a mark. The first parameter indicates whether the
gradient should be linear or radial. The second is a set of customisation options
for the colors, positioning and rate of change of the gradient. For example,
to set a radial red-blue color gradient for a mark:

    maColorGradient grRadial [ grStops [ ( 0, "red" ), ( 1, "blue" ) ] ]

values.name: maContinuousBandSize
values.comment: Continuous band size of a bar mark.

values.name: maCursor
values.comment: Cursor to be associated with a hyperlink mark.

values.name: maDiscreteBandSize
values.comment: Discrete band size of a bar mark.

values.name: maDx
values.comment: Horizontal offset between a text mark and its anchor.

values.name: maDy
values.comment: Vertical offset between a text mark and its anchor.

values.name: maExtent
values.comment: Extent of whiskers used in a boxplot, error bars or error bands.

values.name: maFill
values.comment:
Default fill color of a mark. Color strings can use any valid HTML color
specification. For example,

    maColor "#eee"

    maColor "#734FD8"

    maColor "crimson"

    maColor "rgb(255,204,210)"

    maColor "hsl(180, 50%, 50%)"

values.name: maFillGradient
values.comment:
A color gradient to apply to a mark's interior. The first parameter indicates
whether the gradient should be linear or radial. The second is a set of customisation
options for the colors, positioning and rate of change of the gradient. For example,
to set a radial red-blue color gradient as a fill for a mark:

    maStrokeGradient grRadial [ grStops [ ( 0, "red" ), ( 1, "blue" ) ] ]

Fill gradients have a higher priority than [maColorGradient](#maColorGradient).

values.name: maFillOpacity
values.comment: Fill opacity of a mark.

values.name: maFilled
values.comment:
Whether or not a mark's color should be used as the fill color instead of
stroke color.

values.name: maFont
values.comment:
Font of a text mark. Can be any font name made accessible via
a css file (or a generic font like `serif`, `monospace` etc.).

values.name: maFontSize
values.comment: Font size in pixels used by a text mark.

values.name: maFontStyle
values.comment: Font style (e.g. `italic`) used by a text mark.

values.name: maFontWeight
values.comment: Font weight used by a text mark.

values.name: maHRef
values.comment: Hyperlink to be associated with a mark making it a clickable hyperlink.

values.name: maHeight
values.comment: Explicitly set the height of a mark.

values.name: maInterpolate
values.comment:
Interpolation method used by line and area marks. For example to create a
curved line joining data points:

    line [ maInterpolate miMonotone ]

values.name: maLine
values.comment:
Appearance of a line marker joining the vertices of an area mark.

    area
        [ maLine (lmMarker [ maStroke "black" ])
        , maInterpolate miMonotone
        ]

values.name: maMedian
values.comment: Median line properties for the boxplot mark.

values.name: maOpacity
values.comment:
Overall opacity of a mark in the range 0 (completely transparent) to 1
(completely opaque).

values.name: maOrder
values.comment:
Ordering of vertices in a line or area mark. If true (default), order is
determined by measurement type or order channel. If false, the original data order
is used.

values.name: maOrient
values.comment: Orientation of a non-stacked bar, tick, area or line mark.

values.name: maOutliers
values.comment: Outlier symbol properties for the boxplot mark.

values.name: maPoint
values.comment:
Appearance of a point marker joining the vertices of a line or area mark.

    line [ maPoint (pmMarker [ maFill "black" ]) ]

values.name: maRadius
values.comment: Polar coordinate radial offset of a text mark from its origin.

values.name: maRule
values.comment: Rule (main line) properties for the errorbar and boxplot marks.

values.name: maShape
values.comment: Shape of a point mark.

values.name: maShortTimeLabels
values.comment: Whether or not month and weekday names are abbreviated in a text mark.

values.name: maSize
values.comment:
Size of a mark in square units. For example to create a circle of diameter
50 pixels,

    circle [ maSize 2500 ]

values.name: maStroke
values.comment:
Default stroke color of a mark. Color strings can use any valid HTML color
specification. For example,

    maColor "#eee"

    maColor "#734FD8"

    maColor "crimson"

    maColor "rgb(255,204,210)"

    maColor "hsl(180, 50%, 50%)"

values.name: maStrokeCap
values.comment: Cap style of a mark's stroke.

values.name: maStrokeDash
values.comment:
Stroke dash style used by a mark. Determined by an alternating 'on-off'
sequence of line lengths.

values.name: maStrokeDashOffset
values.comment: Number of pixels before the first line dash is drawn.

values.name: maStrokeGradient
values.comment:
A color gradient to apply to a mark's bounary stroke. The first parameter indicates
whether the gradient should be linear or radial. The second is a set of customisation
options for the colors, positioning and rate of change of the gradient. For example,
to set a radial red-blue color gradient for a mark's stroke:

    maStrokeGradient grRadial [ grStops [ ( 0, "red" ), ( 1, "blue" ) ] ]

Stroke gradients have a higher priority than [maColorGradient](#maColorGradient).

values.name: maStrokeJoin
values.comment: Line segment join style of a mark's stroke.

values.name: maStrokeMiterLimit
values.comment: Mitre limit at which to bevel a join between line segments of a mark's stroke.

values.name: maStrokeOpacity
values.comment: Stroke opacity of a mark in the range 0 to 1.

values.name: maStrokeWidth
values.comment: Stroke width of a mark in pixel units.

values.name: maStyle
values.comment:
Names of custom styles to apply to a mark. Each should refer to a named style
defined in a separate style configuration.

values.name: maTension
values.comment: Interpolation tension used when interpolating line and area marks.

values.name: maText
values.comment: Placeholder text for a text mark for when a text channel is not specified.

values.name: maTheta
values.comment:
Polar coordinate angle (clockwise from north in radians) of a text mark from
the origin determined by its x and y properties.

values.name: maThickness
values.comment: Thickness of a tick mark.

values.name: maTicks
values.comment: Tick properties for the errorbar or boxplot mark.

values.name: maTooltip
values.comment: Source of a mark's tooltip content.

values.name: maWidth
values.comment: Explicitly set the width of a mark (e.g. bar width)

values.name: maX
values.comment: X position of a mark.

values.name: maX2
values.comment: X2 position (secondary x value for lines and areal marks).

values.name: maX2Offset
values.comment: X2 position offset for a mark.

values.name: maXOffset
values.comment: X position offset for a mark.

values.name: maY
values.comment: Y position of a mark.

values.name: maY2
values.comment: Y2 position (secondary y value for lines and areal marks).

values.name: maY2Offset
values.comment: Y2 position offset for a mark.

values.name: maYOffset
values.comment: Y position offset for a mark.

values.name: mercator
values.comment:
A Mercator map projection. This is the default projection of longitude,latitude
values if no projection is set explicitly. It preserves shape (local angle) and lines
of equal angular bearing remain parallel straight lines. But area is significantly
enlarged towards the poles.

values.name: miBasis
values.comment: Cubic basis spline interpolation between points anchored at first and last points.

values.name: miBasisClosed
values.comment: Closed cubic basis spline interpolation between points forming a polygon.

values.name: miBasisOpen
values.comment:
Open cubic basis spline interpolation between points, which may not intersect
first and last points.

values.name: miBundle
values.comment: Bundle curve interpolation between points.

values.name: miCardinal
values.comment:
Cubic cardinal spline interpolation between points anchored at first and last
points.

values.name: miCardinalClosed
values.comment: Closed cubic cardinal spline interpolation between points forming a polygon.

values.name: miCardinalOpen
values.comment:
Open cubic cardinal spline interpolation between points, which may not intersect
first and last points

values.name: miLinear
values.comment: Linear (straight) interpolation between points.

values.name: miMonotone
values.comment: Cubic spline interpolation that preserves monotonicity between points.

values.name: miStepAfter
values.comment: Piecewise (stepped) constant interpolation function after each point in a sequence.

values.name: miStepBefore
values.comment: Piecewise (stepped) constant interpolation function before each point in a sequence.

values.name: miStepwise
values.comment:
Piecewise (stepped) constant interpolation function centred on each point in
a sequence.

values.name: milliseconds
values.comment: Milliseconds time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: minutes
values.comment: Minute of the hour time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: minutesSeconds
values.comment: Minutes and seconds time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: moHorizontal
values.comment: Indicate horizontal mark orientation.

values.name: moVertical
values.comment: Indicate vertical mark orientation.

values.name: month
values.comment: Month of the year (1-12) time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: monthDate
values.comment: Month and day of month time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: monthDateHours
values.comment: Month, day of month and hour of day time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: name
values.comment: Name to be associated with a visualization.

values.name: niDay
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded days.

values.name: niFalse
values.comment: Disable nice scaling.

values.name: niHour
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded hours.

values.name: niInterval
values.comment: 'Nice' temporal interval values when scaling.

values.name: niMillisecond
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with rounded milliseconds.

values.name: niMinute
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded minutes.

values.name: niMonth
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded months.

values.name: niSecond
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded seconds.

values.name: niTickCount
values.comment: Desired number of tick marks in a 'nice' scaling.

values.name: niTrue
values.comment: Enable nice scaling.

values.name: niWeek
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded weeks.

values.name: niYear
values.comment: Nice time intervals that try to align with whole or rounded years.

values.name: noClip
values.comment: Indicate no clipping to be applied.

values.name: noData
values.comment: Ignore the data of a specification's parent when used in a composed spec.

values.name: not
values.comment:
Apply a negation Boolean operation as part of a logical composition. Boolean
operations can be nested to any level.

    not (and (expr "datum.IMDB_Rating === null") (expr "datum.Rotten_Tomatoes_Rating === null"))

values.name: nullValue
values.comment:
An unspecified data value. Can be useful when explicitly recoding a value as
undefined. For example:

    data =
        dataFromRows []
            << dataRow [ ( "x", num 1 ), ( "y", num 10 ) ]
            << dataRow [ ( "x", num 2 ), ( "y", nullValue ) ]
            << dataRow [ ( "x", num 3 ), ( "y", num 30 ) ]

For more complex data sources that contain lists of defined and unspecified values,
consider using [dataFromJson](#dataFromJson) instead.

values.name: num
values.comment: A numeric data value.

values.name: numRange
values.comment: Minimum-maximum number range to be used in data filtering.

values.name: nums
values.comment:
List of numeric data values. Used when declaring inline data with
[dataColumn](#dataColumn), filtering ([fiOneOf](#fiOneOf)), imputation
([imKeyVals](#imKeyVals)) and customized sorting ([soCustom](#soCustom)).

values.name: oAggregate
values.comment:
Compute some aggregate summary statistics for a field to be encoded with an
order channel. The type of aggregation is determined by the given operation
parameter.

values.name: oBin
values.comment: Discretize numeric values into bins when encoding with an order channel.

values.name: oGeo
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded with an order channel is a geo feature. Equivalent
to `oMType GeoFeature`.

values.name: oMType
values.comment:
Level of measurement when encoding with an order channel. See also
[oNominal](#oNominal), oOrdinal](#oOrdinal), [oQuant](#oQuant),
[oTemporal](#oTemporal) and [oGeo](#oGeo) for shorthand equivalents.

values.name: oName
values.comment: Name of field used for encoding with an order channel.

values.name: oNominal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded with an order channel is nominal. Equivalent to
`oMType Nominal`.

values.name: oOrdinal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded with an order channel is ordinal. Equivalent to
`oMType Ordinal`.

values.name: oQuant
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded with an order channel is quantitative. Equivalent
to `oMType Quantitative`.

values.name: oRepeat
values.comment:
Reference in a order channel to a field name generated by [repeatFlow](#repeatFlow)
or [repeat](#repeat). The parameter identifies whether reference is being made to
fields that are to be arranged in columns, in rows or a with a flow layout.

values.name: oSort
values.comment: Sort order to be used by an order channel.

values.name: oTemporal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded with an order channel is temporal. Equivalent to
`oMType Temporal`.

values.name: oTimeUnit
values.comment: Time unit aggregation of field values when encoding with an order channel.

values.name: opArgMax
values.comment:
An input data object containing the minimum field value to be used in an
aggregation operation. If supplied as part of an encoding aggregation, the parameter
should be `Just` the name of the field to maximise. For example the following would
find the production budget for the maximum US grossing film in each genre.

    encoding
        << position X
            [ pName "Production_Budget"
            , pMType Quantitative
            , pAggregate (opArgMax (Just "US_Gross"))
            ]
        << position Y [ pName "Major_Genre", pMType Nominal ]

If supplied as part of a transform, the parameter should be `Nothing` as the field
is specified in the [aggregate](#aggregate) parameter. For example,

    trans =
        transform
            << aggregate
                [ opAs (opArgMax Nothing) "US_Gross" "amUSGross" ]
                [ "Major_Genre" ]

values.name: opArgMin
values.comment:
An input data object containing the minimum field value to be used in an
aggregation operation.

values.name: opAs
values.comment:
Aggregation operation. The first parameter is the operation to use; the second
the name of the field in which to apply it and the third the name to be given to
this transformation.

    trans =
        transform
            << aggregate
                [ opAs opMin "people" "lowerBound"
                , opAs opMax "people" "upperBound"
                ]
                [ "age" ]

If the operation is `Count`, it does not apply to any specific field, so the second
parameter can be an empty string.

values.name: opCI0
values.comment: Lower 95% confidence interval to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opCI1
values.comment: Upper 95% confidence interval to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opCount
values.comment: Total count of data objects to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opDistinct
values.comment: Count of distinct data objects to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opMax
values.comment: Maximum field value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opMean
values.comment: Mean value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opMedian
values.comment: Median field value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opMin
values.comment: Minimum field value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opMissing
values.comment: Count of null or undefined field value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opQ1
values.comment: Lower quartile boundary of field values to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opQ3
values.comment: Upper quartile boundary of field values to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opStderr
values.comment: Standard error of field values to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opStdev
values.comment: Sample standard deviation of field values to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opStdevP
values.comment: Population standard deviation of field values to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opSum
values.comment: Sum of field values to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opValid
values.comment:
Count of values that are not `null`, `undefined` or `NaN` to be used in an
aggregation operation.

values.name: opVariance
values.comment: Sample variance of field value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opVarianceP
values.comment: Population variance of field value to be used in an aggregation operation.

values.name: opacity
values.comment: Encode an opacity channel.
values.type: List.List VegaLite.MarkChannel -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: or
values.comment: Apply an 'or' Boolean operation as part of a logical composition.

values.name: order
values.comment:
Encode an order channel. The first parameter is a list of order encoding
options such as the data to encode, sort direction etc.

    enc =
        encoding
            << order [ oName "yield", oMType Ordinal, oSort [ soDescending ] ]
values.type: List.List VegaLite.OrderChannel -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: orthographic
values.comment: An orthographic map projection.

values.name: osGreedy
values.comment: Greedy overlap strategy to be applied when there is not space to show all items on an axis.

values.name: osNone
values.comment: No overlap strategy to be applied when there is not space to show all items on an axis.

values.name: osParity
values.comment:
Give all items equal weight in overlap strategy to be applied when there is
not space to show them all on an axis.

values.name: pAggregate
values.comment:
Compute some aggregate summary statistics for a field to be encoded with a
position channel. The type of aggregation is determined by the given operation
parameter.

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X [ pName "role", pMType Ordinal ]
            << position Y
                [ pName "salary"
                , pMType Quantitative
                , pAggregate opMean
                ]

values.name: pAxis
values.comment:
Axis properties used when encoding with a position channel. For no axis,
provide an empty list.

values.name: pBin
values.comment:
Discretize numeric values into bins when encoding with a position channel.
For non-default binning, bin-widths, extent etc. can be specified in the first ]
parameter. For example, to encode a frequency histogram with bins every 5 units,

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X [ pName "x", pMType Ordinal, pBin [ biStep 5 ] ]
            << position Y [ pMType Quantitative, pAggregate opCount ]

values.name: pBinned
values.comment: Indicate that data encoded with position are already binned.

values.name: pGeo
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a position is a geo feature. Equivalent to
`pMType GeoFeature`.

values.name: pHeight
values.comment:
Set the position to the height of the enclosing data space. Useful for placing
a mark relative to the bottom edge of a view.

values.name: pImpute
values.comment:
Imputation rules for a position channel. See the
[Vega-Lite impute documentation](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/impute.html)
For example, to impute the missing value of `b` with the mean of existing `b` values,
when `a` is 30 and its color group (`c`) is 1:

    let
        data =
            dataFromColumns []
                << dataColumn "a" (nums [ 0, 0, 10, 10, 20, 20, 30 ])
                << dataColumn "b" (nums [ 28, 91, 43, 55, 81, 53, 19 ])
                << dataColumn "c" (nums [ 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 ])

        enc =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "a", pMType Quantitative ]
                << position Y
                    [ pName "b"
                    , pMType Quantitative
                    , pImpute [ imMethod imMean ]
                    ]
                << color [ mName "c", mMType Nominal ]
    in
    toVegaLite [ data [], enc [], line [] ]

values.name: pMType
values.comment:
Level of measurement when encoding with a position channel. See also
[pNominal](#pNominal), [pOrdinal](#pOrdinal), [pQuant](#pQuant), [pTemporal](#pTemporal)
and [pGeo](#pGeo) for shorthand equivalents.

values.name: pName
values.comment: Name of field used for encoding with a position channel.

values.name: pNominal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a position is nominal. Equivalent to
`pMType Nominal`.

values.name: pNum
values.comment:
Set a position to an arbitrary value. Useful for placing items at the top of
a plot area (`pNum 0`) or a fixed number of pixels from the top.

values.name: pOrdinal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a position is ordinal. Equivalent to
`pMType Ordinal`.

values.name: pQuant
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a position is quantitative. Equivalent to
`pMType Quantitative`.

values.name: pRepeat
values.comment:
Reference in a position channel to a field name generated by [repeatFlow](#repeatFlow)
or [repeat](#repeat). The parameter identifies whether reference is being made to
fields that are to be arranged in columns, in rows or a with a flow layout.

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X [ pRepeat arFlow, pMType Quantitative ]

    spec =
          asSpec [ data [], tick [], enc [] ]

    toVegaLite
        [ repeatFlow [ "Horsepower", "Miles_per_Gallon", "Acceleration"]
        , specification spec
        ]

values.name: pScale
values.comment:
Scaling applied to a field when encoding with a position channel.
The scale will transform a field's value into a position along one axis.

For example, the following will scale the bars positioned along a horizontal axis
to have an inner spacing of 50% (0.5) of the total space allocated to each bar.

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X
                [ pName "ageGroup"
                , pMType Nominal
                , pScale [ scPaddingInner 0.5 ]
                ]

values.name: pSort
values.comment: Sort order for field when encoding with a position channel.

values.name: pStack
values.comment:
Type of stacking offset for field when encoding with a position channel. For
example, stacking areas away from a centreline can be used to create a
[streamgraph](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/examples/stacked_area_stream.html):

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X [ pName "week", pMType Ordinal ]
            << position Y
                [ pName "takings"
                , pMType Quantitative
                , pStack stCenter
                ]
            << color [ mName "shop", mMType Nominal ]

values.name: pTemporal
values.comment:
Indicate a data field encoded as a position is temporal. Equivalent to
`pMType Temporal`.

values.name: pTimeUnit
values.comment: Form of time unit aggregation of field values when encoding with a position channel.

values.name: pTitle
values.comment: Title of a field when encoding with a position channel.

values.name: pWidth
values.comment:
Set the position to the width of the enclosing data space. Useful for justifying
a mark to the right hand edge of a view. e.g. to position a mark at the right of
the data rectangle:

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X [ pWidth ]

values.name: paEdges
values.comment:
Padding around a visualization in pixel units. The four parameters
refer to _left_, _top_, _right_, and _bottom_ edges respectively.

values.name: paSize
values.comment: Indicate uniform padding around a visualization in pixel units.

values.name: padding
values.comment:
Padding around the visualization in pixel units. The way padding is interpreted
will depend on the `autosize` properties.

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Parsing rules when processing some data text, specified as a list of tuples
in the form (_fieldname_, _datatype_). Useful when automatic type inference needs
to be overridden, for example when converting integers representing years into dates
and strings into numbers:

    data =
        dataFromUrl "myDataFile.csv"
            [ parse [ ( "year", foDate "%Y" ), ( "y", foNum ) ] ]

values.name: piGroupBy
values.comment:
The data fields to group by when pivoting. If not specified, a single group
containing all data objects will be used.

values.name: piLimit
values.comment:
Maximum number of fields to generate when pivoting. If 0 or unspecified, all
fields are pivoted. The pivot names are sorted in ascending order before any limit
is applied.

values.name: piOp
values.comment: The aggregation to apply to grouped fields during a pivot.

values.name: pivot
values.comment:
Perform a _pivot_ operation on a table. Spreads a key-value pair of fields across
multiple fields according to the data in the _key_ field. The first two parameters
are the key and value fields respectively. The third is a set of customisation options.
This performs the same function as
['spread' in the Tidy Elm package](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/gicentre/tidy/latest/Tidy#spread)
and the [pivot_wider](https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/dev/articles/pivot.html) /
[spread](https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/reference/spread.html) operation in the R
tidyverse. It is the inverse of [fold](#fold).

    data =
        dataFromColumns []
            << dataColumn "city" (strs [ "Bristol", "Bristol", "Sheffield", "Sheffield", "Glasgow", "Glasgow" ])
            << dataColumn "temperature" (nums [ 12, 14, 11, 13, 7, 10 ])
            << dataColumn "year" (nums [ 2017, 2018, 2017, 2018, 2017, 2018 ])

    trans =
        transform
            << pivot "year" "temperature" [ piGroupBy [ "city" ] ]

    enc =
        encoding
            -- 2017 temperatures for the Bristol, Sheffield and Glasgow
            << position X [ pName "2017", pMType Quantitative ]
            << position Y [ pName "city", pMType Nominal ]
values.type: String.String -> String.String -> List.List VegaLite.PivotProperty -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: pmMarker
values.comment:
Properties of a point marker that is overlaid on a line or area mark. Used
when specifying an [maPoint](#maPoint).

values.name: pmNone
values.comment: No point marker to be shown on a line or area mark.

values.name: pmTransparent
values.comment:
Transparent point marker to be placed on area or line mark. Useful for
interactive selections.

values.name: point
values.comment:
[Point mark](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/point.html) for
symbolising a data point with a symbol.

values.name: position
values.comment:
Encode a position channel. The first parameter identifies the channel, the
second a list of position encoding options.

    enc =
        encoding
            << position X [ pName "month", pMType Temporal ]
            << position Y [ pName "numHires", pMType Quantitative ]
values.type: VegaLite.Position -> List.List VegaLite.PositionChannel -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: prCenter
values.comment: Projections center as longitude and latitude in degrees.

values.name: prClipAngle
values.comment:
Projections clipping circle radius to the specified angle in degrees.
A value of `Nothing` will switch to antimeridian cutting rather than small-circle
clipping.

values.name: prClipExtent
values.comment: Projections viewport clip extent to the specified bounds in pixels.

values.name: prCoefficient
values.comment: 'Hammer' map projection coefficient.

values.name: prDistance
values.comment: 'Satellite' map projection distance.

values.name: prFraction
values.comment: `Bottomley` map projection fraction.

values.name: prLobes
values.comment: Number of lobes in lobed map projections such as the 'Berghaus star'.

values.name: prParallel
values.comment: Parallel for map projections such as the 'Armadillo'.

values.name: prPrecision
values.comment:
Threshold for the projections adaptive resampling in pixels.
Corresponds to the DouglasPeucker distance. If precision is not specified, the
projections current resampling precision of 0.707 is used.

values.name: prRadius
values.comment: Radius value for map projections such as the 'Gingery'.

values.name: prRatio
values.comment: Ratio value for map projections such as the 'Hill'.

values.name: prReflectX
values.comment:
Reflect the x-coordinates after performing an identity projection. This
creates a left-right mirror image of the geoshape marks when subject to an
[identityProjection](#identityProjection).

values.name: prReflectY
values.comment:
Reflect the y-coordinates after performing an identity projection. This
creates a top-bottom mirror image of the geoshape marks when subject to an
[identityProjection](#identityProjection).

values.name: prRotate
values.comment:
A projections three-axis rotation angle. This should be in order _lambda phi
gamma_ specifying the rotation angles in degrees about each spherical axis.

values.name: prScale
values.comment:
A projections zoom scale, which if set, overrides automatic scaling of a
geo feature to fit within the viewing area.

values.name: prSpacing
values.comment: Spacing value for map projections such as the 'Lagrange'.

values.name: prTilt
values.comment: 'Satellite' map projection tilt.

values.name: prTranslate
values.comment:
A projections panning translation, which if set, overrides automatic positioning
of a geo feature to fit within the viewing area.

values.name: prType
values.comment: Type of global map projection.

values.name: projection
values.comment:
Map projection used for geospatial coordinates.

    proj =
        projection [ prType equirectangular, prRotate -156 0 0 ]

values.name: quarter
values.comment: Year quarter time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: quarterMonth
values.comment: Year quarter and month time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: raName
values.comment: Name of a pre-defined scale range (e.g. `symbol` or `diverging`).

values.name: raNums
values.comment:
Numeric scale range. Depending on the scaling this may be a [min, max]
pair, or a list of explicit numerical values.

values.name: raStrs
values.comment: Text scale range for discrete scales.

values.name: racoCategory
values.comment: Default color scheme for categorical ranges.

values.name: racoDiverging
values.comment: Default diverging color scheme.

values.name: racoHeatmap
values.comment: Default 'heatmap' color scheme.

values.name: racoOrdinal
values.comment: Default ordinal color scheme.

values.name: racoRamp
values.comment: Default ramp (continuous) color scheme.

values.name: racoSymbol
values.comment: Default color scheme symbols.

values.name: reAxis
values.comment:
Indicate how a channel's axes should be resolved when defined in more than
one view in a composite visualization.

values.name: reIndependent
values.comment: Channel should be independent of others in a composite visualization.

values.name: reLegend
values.comment:
Indicate how a channel's legends should be resolved when defined in more
than one view in a composite visualization.

values.name: reScale
values.comment:
Indicate how a channel's scales should be resolved when defined in more
than one view in a composite visualization.

values.name: reShared
values.comment: Channel should be shared with others in a composite visualization.

values.name: rect
values.comment: [Rectangle mark](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/rect.html).

values.name: regression
values.comment:
Generate a 2d regression model for smoothing and predicting data. The first
parameter is the name of the field representing the dependent variable (commonly
mapped to the y-axis), the second is the name of the field representing the
independent variable (commonly mapped to the x-axis). The third parameter is a
list of optional regression customisation options.
values.type: String.String -> String.String -> List.List VegaLite.RegressionProperty -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Define the fields that will be used to compose rows and columns of a set of
small multiples. Similar to [repeatFlow](#repeatFlow) except that the fields for
repetition by rows or by columns are set explicitly.

Unlike _faceting_, which creates multiple charts based on different values of a
single field, _repeating_ uses a different field for each chart.

    spec = asSpec [...]
    toVegaLite
        [ repeat [ columnFields [ "Cat", "Dog", "Fish" ] ]
        , specification spec
        ]

values.name: repeatFlow
values.comment:
Define the fields that will be used to compose a flow layout of a set of
small multiples. Used when the encoding is largely identical, but the data field
used in each might vary. When a list of fields is identified with `repeat` you also
need to define a full specification to apply to each of those fields using `asSpec`.

Small multiples will be laid out from left to right, moving on to new rows only
if the number of plots exceeds an optional column limit (specified via
[columns](#columns)).

    spec = asSpec [...]
    toVegaLite
        [ repeatFlow [ "Cat", "Dog", "Fish" ]
        , specification spec
        ]

values.name: resolution
values.comment:
Define a resolution option to be applied when scales, axes or legends in composite
views share channel encodings. For example, it allows different color scales to be
used in a layered view, or different axis scales to be used in a faceted view. Each
resolution rule should be in a tuple pairing the channel to which it applies and
the rule type. The first parameter identifies the type of resolution.

    resolve
        << resolution (reScale [ ( chY, reIndependent ) ])
        << resolution (reScale [ ( chColor, reIndependent ) ])
        << resolution (reLegend [ ( chShape, reShared ) ])

values.name: resolve
values.comment:
Determine whether or not scales, axes or legends in composite views should
share channel encodings.

    let
        data =
            dataFromColumns []
                << dataColumn "x" (nums [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ])
                << dataColumn "a" (nums [ 28, 91, 43, 55, 81 ])
                << dataColumn "b" (nums [ 17, 22, 28, 30, 40 ])

        encBar =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "x", pMType Quantitative ]
                << position Y [ pName "a", pMType Quantitative ]

        specBar =
            asSpec [ bar [], encBar [] ]

        encLine =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "x", pMType Quantitative ]
                << position Y [ pName "b", pMType Quantitative ]

        specLine =
            asSpec [ line [ maColor "firebrick" ], encLine [] ]

        res =
            resolve
                << resolution (reScale [ ( chY, reIndependent ) ])
    in
    toVegaLite [ data [], res [], layer [ specBar, specLine ] ]

values.name: rgAs
values.comment:
Name the outputs of a regression transform. The first parameter is the name to
give the field containing the independent variable, the second the name to
give the field containing dependent variable. If not specified, the
original input independent and dependent field names are used.

values.name: rgExp
values.comment: Indicates an exponential regression method.

values.name: rgExtent
values.comment:
The min (first parameter) - max (second parameter) domain over which to estimate
the dependent variable in a regression. If unspecified, the full extent of input
values will be used.

values.name: rgGroupBy
values.comment:
The data fields to group by when generating a regression model. If not
specified, a single group containing all data objects will be used.

values.name: rgLinear
values.comment: Indicates a linear regression method.

values.name: rgLog
values.comment: Indicates a log regression method.

values.name: rgMethod
values.comment: The type of regression model to use when generating a 2d regression.

values.name: rgOrder
values.comment:
The order of a polynomial model to use when generating a 2d regression. Only
applies if [rgMethod](#rgMethod) is set to [rgPoly](#rgPoly).

values.name: rgPoly
values.comment:
Indicates a polynomial regression method. The order of the polynomial can be
set with [rgOrder](#rgOrder) (defaulting to cubic if not provided).

values.name: rgPow
values.comment: Indicates a power regression method.

values.name: rgQuad
values.comment: Indicates a quadratic regression method.

values.name: rgb
values.comment:
RGB color interpolation for continuous color scales using the given gamma
value (anchored at 1).

values.name: row
values.comment:
Encode a new facet to be arranged in rows. The first parameter is a list of
facet properties that define the faceting channel. See the
[Vega-Lite row documentation](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/facet.html#row--column-encoding-channels).

Note that when faceting, dimensions specified with [width](#width) and [height](#height)
refer to the individual faceted plots, not the assemblage as a whole.

    let
        data =
            dataFromUrl "crimeData.csv"

        enc =
            encoding
                << position X [ pName "month", pMType Temporal ]
                << position Y
                    [ pName "reportedCrimes"
                    , pMType Quantitative
                    , pAggregate opSum
                    , pAxis [ axTitle "" ]
                    ]
                << row [ fName "crimeType", fMType Nominal ]
    in
    toVegaLite [ height 80, data [], bar [], enc [] ]
values.type: List.List VegaLite.FacetChannel -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: rowBy
values.comment:
The mapping between a row and its field definitions in a set of faceted
small multiples. This is used when specifying a more flexible [facet](#facet)
rather than the compact, but simplified, [row](#row).

values.name: rowFields
values.comment:
Create a list of fields to use in set of repeated small multiples arranged in
rows. The list of fields named here can be referenced in an encoding with
`pRepeat row`, `mRepeat row` etc.

values.name: rule
values.comment:
[Rule line](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/rule.html) connecting
two vertices.

values.name: sacoBandPaddingInner
values.comment: Default inner padding for x and y band-ordinal scales.

values.name: sacoBandPaddingOuter
values.comment: Default outer padding for x and y band-ordinal scales.

values.name: sacoBarBandPaddingInner
values.comment: Default inner padding for x and y band-ordinal scales of `bar` marks.

values.name: sacoBarBandPaddingOuter
values.comment: Default outer padding for x and y band-ordinal scales of `bar` marks.

values.name: sacoClamp
values.comment:
Whether or not by default values that exceed the data domain are clamped to
the min/max range value.

values.name: sacoMaxBandSize
values.comment:
Default maximum value for mapping quantitative fields to a bar's
size/bandSize.

values.name: sacoMaxFontSize
values.comment:
Default maximum value for mapping a quantitative field to a text
mark's size.

values.name: sacoMaxOpacity
values.comment:
Default maximum opacity (in the range [0, 1]) for mapping a field
to opacity.

values.name: sacoMaxSize
values.comment: Default maximum size for point-based scales.

values.name: sacoMaxStrokeWidth
values.comment: Default maximum stroke width for rule, line and trail marks.

values.name: sacoMinBandSize
values.comment: Default minimum value for mapping quantitative fields to a bar's size/bandSize.

values.name: sacoMinFontSize
values.comment: Default minimum value for mapping a quantitative field to a text mark's size.

values.name: sacoMinOpacity
values.comment: Default minimum opacity (0 to 1) for mapping a field to opacity.

values.name: sacoMinSize
values.comment: Default minimum size for point-based scales (when not forced to start at zero).

values.name: sacoMinStrokeWidth
values.comment: Default minimum stroke width for rule, line and trail marks.

values.name: sacoPointPadding
values.comment: Default padding for point-ordinal scales.

values.name: sacoRangeStep
values.comment: Deprecated in favour of [vicoStep](#vicoStep).

values.name: sacoRectBandPaddingInner
values.comment: Default inner padding for x and y band-ordinal scales of `rect` marks.

values.name: sacoRectBandPaddingOuter
values.comment: Default outer padding for x and y band-ordinal scales of `rect` marks.

values.name: sacoRound
values.comment:
Whether or not numeric values are rounded to integers when scaling. Useful
for snapping to the pixel grid.

values.name: sacoTextXRangeStep
values.comment: Deprecated in favour of [vicoStep](#vicoStep).

values.name: sacoUseUnaggregatedDomain
values.comment: Whether or not to use the source data range before aggregation.

values.name: sample
values.comment:
Randomly sample rows from a data source up to a given maximum. For example,
to randomly sample 50 values from a sine curve.

    data =
        dataSequenceAs 0 13 0.001 "x"

    trans =
        transform
            << calculateAs "sin(datum.x)" "y"
            << sample 50

values.name: scAlign
values.comment:
Alignment of the steps within the scale range. Parameter is capped between 0
and 1 where 0.5 indicates steps are centred within range, 0 shifts bands to an
axis, 1 away from axis.

values.name: scBand
values.comment: A band scale.

values.name: scBase
values.comment: The base to use for log scaling.

values.name: scBinLinear
values.comment: A linear band scale.

values.name: scBinOrdinal
values.comment: An ordinal band scale.

values.name: scClamp
values.comment:
Whether or not values outside the data domain are clamped to the minimum or
maximum value.

values.name: scConstant
values.comment:
The desired desired slope of the [scSymLog](#scSymLog) function at zero. If
unspecified, the default is 1.

values.name: scDomain
values.comment: Custom scaling domain.

values.name: scExponent
values.comment: The exponent to use for power scaling.

values.name: scInterpolate
values.comment: Interpolation method for scaling range values.

values.name: scLinear
values.comment: A linear scale.

values.name: scLog
values.comment:
A log scale. Defaults to log of base 10, but can be customised by setting
[scBase](#scBase) to some other value. If data to be scaled contain zeros or negative
values, consider [scSymLog](#scSymLog) instead.

values.name: scNice
values.comment: 'Nice' minimum and maximum values in a scaling (e.g. multiples of 10).

values.name: scOrdinal
values.comment: An ordinal scale.

values.name: scPadding
values.comment: Padding in pixels to apply to a scaling.

values.name: scPaddingInner
values.comment: Inner padding to apply to a band scaling.

values.name: scPaddingOuter
values.comment: Outer padding to apply to a band scaling.

values.name: scPoint
values.comment: A point scale.

values.name: scPow
values.comment:
A power scale. The exponent to use for scaling is specified with
[scExponent](#scExponent).

values.name: scQuantile
values.comment: A quantile scale.

values.name: scQuantize
values.comment: A quantizing scale.

values.name: scRange
values.comment: Range of a scaling. The type of range depends on the encoding channel.

values.name: scRangeStep
values.comment: Deprecated in favour of [widthStep](#widthStep) and [heightStep](#heightStep).

values.name: scReverse
values.comment:
Deprecated in favour of [pSort](#pSort), [mSort](#mSort) or [fSort](#fSort),
providing [soDescending](#soDescending) as the sort order.

values.name: scRound
values.comment: Whether or not numeric values in a scaling are rounded to integers.

values.name: scScheme
values.comment:
Color scheme used by a color scaling with [mScale](#mScale). The first parameter
is the name of the scheme (e.g. "viridis") and the second an optional specification
of the number of colors to use (list of one number), or the extent of the color
range to use (list of two numbers between 0 and 1). For example

    color
        [ mName "value"
        , mMType Ordinal
        , mScale [ scScheme "redblue" [ 0, 0.8 ] ]
        ]

values.name: scSequential
values.comment: Deprecated in favour of [scLinear](#scLinear).

values.name: scSqrt
values.comment: A square root scale.

values.name: scSymLog
values.comment:
A [symmetrical log](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/John_Webber4/publication/233967063_A_bi-symmetric_log_transformation_for_wide-range_data/links/0fcfd50d791c85082e000000.pdf)
scale. Similar to a log scale but supports zero and negative values. The slope
of the function at zero can be set with [scConstant](#scConstant).

values.name: scThreshold
values.comment: A threshold scale.

values.name: scTime
values.comment: A temporal scale.

values.name: scType
values.comment: Type of scaling to apply.

values.name: scUtc
values.comment: A UTC temporal scale.

values.name: scZero
values.comment: Whether or not a numeric scaling should be forced to include a zero value.

values.name: seBind
values.comment:
Bind to some input elements as part of a named selection. For example, to
allow a selection to be based on a drop-down list of options:

    sel =
        selection
            << select "mySelection"
                seSingle
                [ seFields [ "crimeType" ]
                , seBind
                    [ iSelect "crimeType"
                        [ inOptions
                            [ "Anti-social behaviour"
                            , "Criminal damage and arson"
                            , "Drugs"
                            , "Robbery"
                            , "Vehicle crime"
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ]

values.name: seBindScales
values.comment:
Enable two-way binding between a selection and the scales used in the same
view. Commonly used for zooming and panning by binding selection to position scaling:

    sel =
        selection
            << select "mySelection" seInterval [ seBindScales ]

values.name: seClear
values.comment:
[Vega event stream selector](https://vega.github.io/vega/docs/event-streams/#selector)
that can clear a selection. For example, to allow a zoomed/panned view to be reset
on shift-click:

    selection
        << select "myZoomPan"
            seInterval
            [ seBindScales, seClear "click[event.shiftKey]" ]

To remove the default clearing behaviour of a selection, provide an empty string
rather than an event stream selector.

values.name: seEmpty
values.comment: Make a selection empty by default when nothing selected.

values.name: seEncodings
values.comment:
Encoding channels that form a named selection. For example, to _project_ a
selection across all items that share the same value in the color channel:

    sel =
        selection
            << select "mySelection" seMulti [ seEncodings [ chColor ] ]

values.name: seFields
values.comment: Field names for projecting a selection.

values.name: seGlobal
values.comment: One selection available across all subviews (default).

values.name: seInit
values.comment:
Initialise one or more selections with values from bound fields.

    sel =
        selection
            << select "CylYr"
                seSingle
                [ seFields [ "Cylinders", "Year" ]
                , seInit
                    [ ( "Cylinders", num 4 )
                    , ( "Year", num 1977 )
                    ]
                , seBind
                    [ iRange "Cylinders" [ inName "Cylinders ", inMin 3, inMax 8, inStep 1 ]
                    , iRange "Year" [ inName "Year ", inMin 1969, inMax 1981, inStep 1 ]
                    ]
                ]

values.name: seInitInterval
values.comment:
Initialse the domain extent of an interval selection. The parameters refer to
the (xMin, xMax) and (yMin, yMax) domain extents of the initial interval selection.
If one of the tuples is `Nothing` the selection is projected over that dimension.
If both are nothing, no initialization is provided.

Initialise selection between 2013-2015 along x-channel and 40-80 along y-channel:

    select "mySelection"
        seInterval
        [ seInitInterval (Just ( dt [ dtYear 2013 ], dt [ dtYear 2015 ] ))
            (Just ( num 40, num 80 ))
        ]

Initialise selection on the y-channel between 40-80 and project across the x-channel:

    select "mySelection"
        seInterval
        [ seInitInterval Nothing (Just ( num 40, num 80 )) ]
values.type: Maybe.Maybe ( VegaLite.DataValue, VegaLite.DataValue ) -> Maybe.Maybe ( VegaLite.DataValue, VegaLite.DataValue ) -> VegaLite.SelectionProperty

values.name: seIntersection
values.comment:
Each subview contains its own brush and marks are selected if they lie
within _all_ of these individual selections.

values.name: seInterval
values.comment:
Indicate a draggable bounding rectangle can be made for selecting all items
that intersect with it.

values.name: seMulti
values.comment: Indicate multiple interactive mark selections can be made (e.g. with shift-click).

values.name: seNearest
values.comment:
Whether or not a selection should capture nearest marks to a pointer
rather than an exact position match.

values.name: seOn
values.comment:
[Vega event stream selector](https://vega.github.io/vega/docs/event-streams/#selector)
that triggers a selection.

values.name: seResolve
values.comment:
Strategy that determines how selections data queries are resolved when applied
in a filter transform, conditional encoding rule, or scale domain.

values.name: seSelectionMark
values.comment: Appearance of an interval selection mark (dragged rectangle).

values.name: seSingle
values.comment: Indicate a single, mark at a time, interactive selection can be made.

values.name: seToggle
values.comment:
Predicate expression that determines a toggled selection. See the
[Vega-Lite toggle documentation](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/toggle.html)

values.name: seTranslate
values.comment:
Translation selection transformation used for panning a view. See the
[Vega-Lite translate documentation](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/translate.html)

values.name: seUnion
values.comment:
Each subview contains its own brush and marks are selected if they lie
within _any_ of these individual selections.

values.name: seZoom
values.comment:
Zooming selection transformation used for zooming a view. See the
[Vega-Lite zoom documentation](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/docs/zoom.html)

values.name: seconds
values.comment: Second of a minute time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: secondsMilliseconds
values.comment: Seconds and milliseconds time unit used for discretizing temporal data.

values.name: select
values.comment:
Create a single named selection that may be applied to a data query or transformation.
The first two parameters specify the name to be given to the selection for later
reference and the type of selection made. The third allows additional selection options to
be specified.
values.type: String.String -> VegaLite.Selection -> List.List VegaLite.SelectionProperty -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: selected
values.comment:
Interactive selection that will be true or false as part of a logical composition.
e.g., to filter a dataset so that only items selected interactively and that have
a weight of more than 30:

    transform
        << filter (fCompose (and (selected "brush") (expr "datum.weight > 30")))

values.name: selection
values.comment:
Create a full selection specification from a list of selections.

    sel =
        selection
            << select "view" seInterval [ seBindScales ] []
            << select "myBrush" seInterval []
            << select "myPaintbrush" seMulti [ seOn "mouseover", seNearest True ]

values.name: selectionName
values.comment:
Name a selection that is used as part of a conditional encoding.

    color
        [ mSelectionCondition (selectionName "myBrush")
            [ mName "myField", mMType Nominal ]
            [ mStr "grey" ]
        ]

values.name: shape
values.comment:
Encode a shape channel. The first parameter is a list of shape encoding options
such as the data to encode, custom shape encodings etc.

    enc =
        encoding
            << shape [ mName "company", mMType Nominal ]
values.type: List.List VegaLite.MarkChannel -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec -> List.List VegaLite.LabelledSpec

values.name: siBottom
values.comment: Bottom side, used to specify an axis position.

values.name: siLeft
values.comment: Left side, used to specify an axis position.

values.name: siRight
values.comment: Right side, used to specify an axis position.

values.name: siTop
values.comment: Top side, used to specify an axis position.

values.name: size
values.comment:
